Hemoglobin: A protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body.
Total Leukocyte Count: Measures white blood cells that help fight infections.
Neutrophils: White blood cells that protect against bacterial infections.
Lymphocyte: White blood cells involved in immunity and fighting viral infections.
Platelet Count: Blood cells that help stop bleeding by forming clots.
MCV: Shows the average size of red blood cells.
MCH: Shows how much hemoglobin is present in each red blood cell.
MCHC: Shows how concentrated hemoglobin is in red blood cells.
Fasting Blood Sugar: Measures blood sugar after fasting to assess diabetes risk.
Post Prandial Blood Sugar: Measures blood sugar after a meal.
HbA1c: Shows average blood sugar levels over the past 2â€“3 months.
TSH: A hormone that controls thyroid activity and metabolism.
T3: A thyroid hormone that affects energy and metabolism.
T4: A thyroid hormone that regulates body functions.
LH: A hormone that helps regulate ovulation and the menstrual cycle.
FSH: A hormone involved in egg development in the ovaries.
LH/FSH Ratio: Shows the balance between LH and FSH hormones.
Prolactin: A hormone that affects menstrual cycles and milk production.
Testosterone: A hormone present in both genders; higher levels in women may affect ovulation.
Total Cholesterol: Measures overall cholesterol levels in the blood.
LDL Cholesterol: Often called bad cholesterol; high levels may increase heart risk.
HDL Cholesterol: Often called good cholesterol; helps protect the heart.
Triglycerides: A type of fat in the blood that stores excess energy.
SGOT: An enzyme that helps assess liver health.
SGPT: An enzyme that indicates liver cell injury.
Bilirubin: A substance formed from red blood cell breakdown; high levels may cause jaundice.
ALP: An enzyme related to liver and bone health.
Creatinine: A waste product used to evaluate kidney function.
Urea: A waste product that reflects kidney health.
